I'm in my mid 50's and grew up listening to Walter Cronkite ... knew he was married and like to sail. I liked it better when the networks fought over who was better at delivering the news.

We used to have reporters .. new they are personalities.

I guess this view went out with civics .. Andy Warhol was so correct!
Ethics and humility.  These are the qualities needed of a good reporter.  The story is not about you.  You are subordinate to the story.  You check your ego at the door.

Hold on a second.  It's been reported that for years management knew about BW's fanciful accounts and did nothing.  Members of the military contacted them when the Iraqi report was first filed ten years ago and they didn't respond.  His production crews knew what happened on all the stories that are being investigated now and didn't come forward to correct the record, so they should be put on six month's hiatus with no pay also. So should Nancy Sneiderman who lied and broke an Ebola quarantine.  The heads of NBC and NBC Universal should be fired for encouraging BW to blur the lines between news and entertainment by acting the cut up on late night to attract a younger demographic.  Nobody it seems was running the asylum.

To understand just how bad an investment buying a ticket is, you multiply the amount of the payout times the chances of winning and compare it to what you paid for the ticket.

Reducing factors:
> Don't forget that others may win the same time you do thus dividing your winnings.
> Don't forget that what you actually win will be less than the advertised amount because the real amount is what accumulates for years compounding while you are waiting to collect...a big up front payout is usually less for this reason.
> Don't forget taxes

So calculate this for each possible combination of winning and add them all up. Depending on the lottery the average winnings is almost always less than the amount you paid for the ticket....the rare exception is when so much money rolls over when nobody wins that the tickets sold on the last round and they cost less than the accumulated payout.

Example:
If the payout is $1,000,000 dollars on a one dollar ticket and the odds of winning is one in 5,000,000, then the average payout for each dollar invested is 20 cents for the million dollar prize, and the average loss on each dollar invested is 80 cents for that price amount....and this is not taking into account the winning reducing factors.

You add up all the average payouts to see how much the expected return will be, but typically depending on the context, it is not uncommon for this to be about 25 cents on the dollar....again, without taking into account the winning reducing factors.

The only time that history changes the odds is when selected numbers are removed from the pool for the next round. That's not how lotteries work; each drawing is an independent event. When you flip a coin there's an equal chance it will come up heads or tails, even if it came up heads the last 10 times you flipped it.

To believe otherwise is just magical thinking.

My sister will tell me how infintesimally low the chances of winning are (she doesn't buy tickets) and I'll tell her that I know that, but I also know that some people do win and they have bought tickets.
Really? Brian Williams was about 25 years old when Broadcast news was made, so i doubt he was the model.

NBC caused NBC's damage.

Brian Williams, his infotainment, his celebrity, his frivolousness, those are all traits of NBC across the board. Look at Meet the Press. NBC was and is Brian Williams and now that they realize that backfired, they want to be Walter Cronkite.

It's not that easy. You can't fire or suspend yourself a better image. You have to build it was quality selections and hard work over years.
Let's be real, there are many charlatans with advanced degrees. Anonymous snobbishness is the worst kind.

Lester Holt gets my vote. But not because he's black. Because he's good. Let's not hire anyone (for any position, by the way) because someone is black, white, make, female, etc). Let's just get the best person for the job!!

Too bad that they let Ann Curry go; she was the best newsreader the network had.  Hopefully they'll end up giving the job to Lester Holt on a permanent basis.  He has the required credibility and gravitas.  OK, he's black: way past time for one of the networks to hire a black news anchor.

I'm glad to see that not all of society feels obliged to curb their morality.  NBC chose to uphold a standard that may be outdated and out of fashion in our present age of instant information, but is still valued:  trust.  I don't trust much of what I see or hear on the news anymore.  It seems that so many parts of the news and reporting today has been warped by agenda and personal and corporate ideology.  But to stand up and say the touchstone of our business, the face of our own corporation, is not Brian Williams but the trust that you, the viewing public, invest with him, that is what we are all about.  Good for you Mr. Burke
If he wasn't being shot it, I'm not sure it qualifies as a "traumatic event." It was only a "traumatic event" in the fake version.
Um, only Brian (and Hillary) weren't in any traumatic situations.

I'm disappointed that NBC didn't give more credence to the fact that memory isn't some static, perfect instrument of recall----particularly our memories of traumatic events (see the quotes from Elizabeth Loftus in yesterday's NYT). And particularly for people who aren't conditioned like soldiers to be less stressed in traumatic situations. Maybe there's more to the story here, but from what we've been told---recalling being shot at in a war zone and seeing a dead body float by in an area surrounded by death and destruction----I sure wish the network would have cut Brian some slack and helped him create an honorable path to redemption (e.g., "Dear listeners: I've been told that the events that occurred don't match my recollections. I apologize if I've hurt or offended anyone."). He's certainly earned our trust over the years. By acting out like this, a trusted network has fanned the flames of misunderstanding and probably also lost legions of formerly loyal followers. I hope he comes back---maybe running some stories about memory and recall can help pave the way----but if not, I'll watch Brian's newscast again wherever he ends up.

If, by saying that the suits got it right, you mean that they are protecting the financial investment in the brand as a commercial, money making enterprise, then you are correct. I don't think for a second that these suits care about real news.

Really?  I applaud your optimism, but the days of those older NBC newsmen are long gone.  When the news departments became "folded in" to the entertainment departments of the major networks, the writing was on the wall.  Today the "entertainment, the fluff and the pointless stories" ARE the "news".  As the transnational corporations that own the networks are pulling the strings, at all levels, you can be sure the "news" we get has been thoroughly vetted, edited, sanitized and "spiced" to provide exactly the level of phony gravitas we're expected to willingly consume (and believe).  This is neither truth nor journalism.  The "Fourth estate" has been systematically dismantled by corporate bribery and public apathy.  Better check your phone.

David Brinkley, Chet Huntley, David Chancellor and Edwin Newman are all examples of  NBC's proud history of broadcasting the news.   I expect  that NBC will  recover from this incident and return to  delivering the news in the  professional manner of earlier years and leave out the entertainment, the fluff and pointless stories.

NYT - 2/7: Williams, a star anchor who has garnered high ratings for NBC, said he planned eventually to return to the broadcast and "continue my career-long effort to be worthy of the trust of those who place their trust in us."

"Trust in us?" Brian Williams didn't get it. It's "trust in me."
Why why why do so many feel the need to defend this self-aggrandizing, multi-millionaire entertainer?

Yes.....on a professional level the story line is very similar to Broadcast News. On a more personal level, the real life situation of Brian Williams more closely resembles the foibles and fate of one Charles Van Doren of "Quiz Show" fame.
Both men had the world at their fingertips but chose to risk it all by deceiving the Public. No crime was committed in either case but once the Trust of the Public was breached a personal price needed to be extracted.
I frankly never liked this guy. I was always put off by his smarmy sympathy.

NBC advertised Mr. Williams as the most trusted news person in the country and thereby implied that it is the most trusted news network in the country.  It turns out that Mr. Williams isn't trustworthy and, therefore, neither is NBC News.  Now Mr. Williams is paying the consequences for lying. NBC is paying the consequences for letting its supposedly trusted anchor run amok.  All is right with the world.  Schadenfreude has never felt so good. And right.
Somewhere in this chain she reported that she's been working on a time-consuming project.

The helicopter was not in his "convoy." Williams' helicopter was 30 minutes behind the one that got shot at. That's what made the pilot who actually did get shot at mad. You have to parse anchormen's words very, very carefully, they are like politicians. When Williams corrected himself, he said, Oops, it was the helicopter in front of mine that got hit. What he didn't mention was, it was 30 minutes in front.
I second the vote for Rachel Maddow.

Lester Holt is fine. But their star is Rachel Maddow. Maybe let the two of them report the news, with Ms Maddow explaining (in plain language with lots of repetition--her hallmark) what's actually going on. You might say this would have a feminist bias, but that's ok. Women, especially single women with children, are in the upper echelons of the down-trodden regularly targeted by Republicans in their relentless policy of punishment for the poor. Note that the Bush policy of "give it all to the rich" (many of whom are white supremacists) still endures, with newly won Obama healthcare and immigration reforms notable exceptions. And these, they are fighting fiercely in order to prevent further reforms, such as single payer, more progressive taxation (or just a fair share corporate tax), or a carbon tax to realistically address global warming, which is caused by humans from burning fossil fuels. My point here: To get this across, in the face of relentless lies from corporate propagandists, it will take a heap of explaining to do--hence Rachel Maddow. Balanced coverage refers to liberal and conservative policy perspectives, not to a choice between lies and the truth, which is what we have now.

On Mr. Williams: helicopters in his convoy(s) were fired at. Certainly, as all these troops realize, "it could have been me". Recall that David Bloom, a colleague from NBC, actually died during combat at this time; from DVT, but probably aggravated by the conditions of war.

My take back then is that Williams was selected because he was in the mold of Brokaw, but represented no threat (he would gladly wait his turn) and because, as a broadcast journalist, he further would not threaten to challenge Brokaw's legacy by surpassing him. If anyone cares to write the story of NBC News, they should look into the role that Brokaw played in moving his successor along and into the job. Future network anchors are usually anointed ahead of time, picked from the crowd and given choice assignments to prepare them for the big chair. That happened with Brokaw, who was a local reporter in LA before he was dropped into the biggest beat in DC, the White House, and it happened with Williams afterward, he was given high profile assignments.

The "fade out" of television news and network evening newscasts in particular has been reported, even wished, for decades by newspapers. The fact is, they are still the largest "circulation" news outlets in the nation. The cable news channels, which are often treated as though they were nearly equal, reach a fraction of the audience.

Doug Terry

It seems like just yesterday that he became the NBC anchor,which I guess is a sign of how old I'm getting.

As I recall, when Brokaw left and Williams got the job, there was a sentiment that Williams was a sort of dork who was in no sense the equal of Brokaw, but he desperately wanted the job, nobody else did, and network news was dying out anyway, so who cared who got the job. At least that is how I recall it -- he was just a guy who grew up wanting to be an anchor, a star, someone who wanted to have the aura of a Cronkite or a Brokaw, not someone who grew up wanting to be a reporter. So I guess none of this should come as much of a surprise.

Too little, too late.  NBC is culpable because they should have vetted Mr.Williams news stories.  When a news anchor exaggerates his experiences as a newsman, it casts a giant shadow on NBC news.  They too have lost some of their credibility.
It's called "integrity," an ancient concept obviously.

This is a big deal because Mr. Williams said that he was on a chopper that was hit by an rpg, when he wasn't. He said the chopper he was on was forced to land, when it wasn't. As relayed by the pilots who flew the choppers that day, Mr. Williams was 1/2 to 1 hour behind the chopper which was hit by anti-aircraft and would not have even been able to witness the attack. Journalists are held to this standard and have been fired for outright fabrication of a news report.

Concerning "deflate-gate" while not of the gravitas of Watergate, it's hardly a witch-hunt when 11 of 12 balls were misteriously deflated x-number of pounds, making it easier to throw, catch and hold onto the football.

I don't understand why this is such a big deal. The event in question happened 12 years ago and he openly confessed to what was essentially an exaggeration. Because of this he has now "lost all of his credibility" and can no longer be trusted as a news anchor? If every TV journalist was subjected to this standard there would be no one left to host shows. In all seriousness, does anyone posting here honestly care?
This reminds me of the media hype following "deflate gate." Our culture is always looking for the next witch to burn to maintain our contrived sense of unassailable morality.

But didn't Russia abide by that promise for 20 years? Who was it who upset the apple cart? It was the West, expanding NATO and encouraging the overthrow of an elected government in Ukraine by force.

It is too late to force Putin to eat crow. You will get a wider war if you are not careful. And you are pretending that it is all Putin but the rebels have minds and goals of their own. I doubt they are taking orders from Putin.

Maybe Putin could lay down the law to rebels, but will he do it to please Obama?
